name: Naltrexone ER (Vivitrol)
summary: An extended-release injectable formulation of naltrexone used for the treatment of alcohol dependence and prevention of relapse in opioid dependence.
description: Vivitrol is an extended-release intramuscular injection of naltrexone, an opioid receptor antagonist. It blocks the euphoric and sedative effects of opioids and reduces cravings in opioid-dependent patients. It also helps reduce heavy drinking in alcohol use disorder. Unlike oral naltrexone, Vivitrol provides continuous therapeutic levels for one month per injection, improving adherence.

contraindications: Current opioid use or acute withdrawal
Hypersensitivity to naltrexone or formulation components

items: Prevention of relapse to opioid dependence after detoxification

sections.text: Naltrexone is a competitive antagonist at mu-opioid receptors, blocking the euphoric and sedative effects of opioids and reducing cravings; mechanism for alcohol dependence is not fully understood but may involve modulation of the mesolimbic reward pathway.

adult.opioid_dependence: 380 mg intramuscularly every 4 weeks after a minimum 7–10 day opioid-free period

sections.hepatic_impairment: Avoid in acute hepatitis or liver failure; use with caution in moderate impairment
sections.renal_impairment: No adjustment for mild to moderate impairment; use with caution in severe impairment

items: Injection: 380 mg/vial for intramuscular gluteal administration

sections.text: Onset within 2 hours; duration approximately 4 weeks per injection.

sections.black_box: Patients must be opioid-free for a minimum of 7–10 days before initiation to avoid precipitated withdrawal.
other: Potential for severe injection site reactions

items: Baseline and periodic liver function tests
Injection site for necrosis or infection

sections.pregnancy: Category C; use only if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: Use with caution; monitor for hepatic and renal function

items: Patients should carry a medical alert card indicating naltrexone therapy
Naloxone challenge may be performed before initiation if opioid abstinence is uncertain
Patients may be more sensitive to opioids after discontinuation due to loss of tolerance
